content.webTitle: US election briefing for Australia: Trump baselessly claims 'fraud' amid nail-biter results

fields.headline: Trump baselessly claims 'fraud' amid nail-biter results
fields.bodyText: Welcome to today’s US election briefing for Australia. It’s not over. Those who hoped for a swift and emphatic repudiation of Donald Trump, and those who expected a repeat of his fast 2016 electoral college victory, were both left disappointed on election night. At the time of writing, key battleground states still hang in the balance, with both candidates retaining paths to victory. Biden has 224 electoral votes and Trump has 213 – a candidate needs 270 to win the White House. Days of counting – and perhaps recounting – may lie ahead. The inconclusive election result plunged the US into an even greater period of uncertainty, and one set to test the country’s collective nerve – and the guardrails of its democracy – for potentially days or weeks to come. The first test of that nerve came quickly, with the president prematurely claiming – as had been feared – that he’d effectively won the election, claiming states that have not been called and asserting Democrats were trying to steal the election. Shortly before 1am on Wednesday the president tweeted: “We are up BIG, but they are trying to STEAL the Election. We will never let them do it. Votes cannot be cast after the Polls are closed!” There was zero evidence of votes being cast after the polls closed but votes were still being counted – as is legal. Twitter, as it has done several times in the late stage of this campaign, almost immediately added a misinformation label to the tweet. He followed that tweet with a speech at the White House where he accused his opponents of trying to “disenfranchise” his supporters and saying “this is a fraud on the American public”. He said he would go to the supreme court and “… we will win this,” he said. “And as far as I’m concerned, we already have.” The TV network I was watching on – NBC – cut in midway to try to correct his mistruths, pointing out some of the states he claimed he was winning in were still too close to call. Biden, likely anticipating this play, had come out earlier in the night, projecting confidence – both in his position and in the process. Speaking at a late night drive-in rally in Delaware, the Democratic nominee said: “We feel good about where we are. We really do.” “I believe we’re on track to win this election.” Biden emphasised the country had to wait until every vote was counted to determine the winner. I had hoped this edition of the newsletter would be the one to draw a line under this tumultuous election. But it’s clear some of the most volatile and consequential moments still lie ahead. You can follow the latest developments on our liveblog throughout the evening. The big stories Trump has won the key battleground state of Florida, but others including North Carolina, Georgia and Pennsylvania remain too close to call. Democrats looked set to retain control of the House but some disappointing early results cast doubt on hopes to take control of the Senate. You can read all the latest on what we know here. The Florida loss meant Biden’s team was left looking for victory elsewhere in the US. Trump polled well in white, rural areas and pulled off a “bloodbath” in Miami-Dade county, home to 2 million Latinos, killing Biden’s hopes in the state. The first supporter of the far-right QAnon conspiracy theory has won a US House seat. Marjorie Taylor Greene, a Republican businesswoman, was declared the winner in Georgia’s 14th congressional district. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Ilhan Omar, two members of the progressive “Squad” of Democratic congresswomen of colour, led the way in securing re-election to the House on Tuesday. Despite pre-election anxiety, Tuesday was largely a day of peaceful voting with only sporadic reports of incidents of intimidation or misinformation or technological problems with voting machines. A nationwide push to relax drug laws scored significant victories on Tuesday as two states voted to legalise marijuana and Oregon became the first state to decriminalise the possession of small amounts of hard drugs. A federal judge on Monday dismissed a Republican-led petition to throw out 127,000 ballots cast at drive-through voting sites in Texas, the latest in a string of attempts by the party to cast doubt over the validity of drive-through and mail-in voting. Quote of the day Keep the faith.” Biden’s closing message to supporters during his late night address. Election views “As they wait for the results, Americans need to take a cue from the Brits: keep calm and carry on,” writes Jill Filipovic. Trump may seek to claim the election prematurely, and exploit people’s desire for closure. “The only bulwark against that is steadied stamina, and willingness to wait.” “Trump desperately wants to retain the presidency – not to ‘keep America great’ but to protect himself from future prosecution,” writes Samer S Shehata. “If Trump loses the election, there may be calls to investigate and prosecute him for possible crimes involving obstruction of justice, violating the emolument clause of the constitution, and/or tax fraud, among others.” Video of the day Here’s Biden’s late night speech to supporters in Delaware, where he sought to buoy hopes amid confusing and inconclusive results. Around the web “Early returns revealed no winner but affirmed the persistence of national fissures, as Democrats who had indulged in fantasies about the instant catharsis of a sweeping victory were left once more to wonder if they understood America as well as they had assumed.” An excellent piece of analysis in the NYT. There’s a lot we don’t know but one thing is clear – the Democrats burned through an eye-watering amount of money on failed Senate races. The Daily Beast calls it a “historic squandering” of resources. A good breakdown of exit poll data here on the Washington Post with some interesting trends – Biden favoured by independents, Trump ahead with those who made a decision in the last week. What the numbers say: 1,130 The number of Americans who died of Covid on election day. Sign up Thanks to everyone who has signed up to receive this briefing as an email every weekday until the election. If you’d like to join them, you can sign up here.
